name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
(Sighs dramatically, pushes sunglasses down my nose, and takes a long sip from a ridiculously oversized, probably-filled-with-something-unhealthy smoothie)

Howard, Howard, Howard. Always with the pressure. You know, for a guy who spent most of my childhood locked away in his lab, inventing the future without actually being present, you sure are keen on dictating mine now.

Okay, look, let's be clear. Summa cum laude at 17? That's not exactly chump change. I've already accomplished more than most people will in their entire lives before I've even hit legal drinking age. And I did it all while maintaining a tan that would make Malibu Ken jealous. So, forgive me if I'm not exactly jumping up and down to immediately chain myself to a desk.

So, while B) Maintain Distance - Dismiss his concerns by saying you "have a plan" and continue relaxing, is tempting...let's tweak it a little.

My answer is B, but with a Stark twist.

I'd wave a dismissive hand, maybe flick a little water at him (just enough to be annoying, not enough to provoke a full-blown Howard Stark lecture). "Relax, Pops. I've got it covered. Got plans bigger than your ego, just you wait." Then, I'd flash that patented Stark smirk and add, "Besides, the world isn't going to save itself. And I'm pretty sure saving the world requires a solid base tan."

Why? Because directly confronting Howard never really worked. He'd just double down. And presenting him with a detailed plan? That's just giving him ammunition to criticize. A little distance, a little mystery, a little arrogance...that's the Stark way. It keeps him guessing, and it gives me time to figure out exactly what I want to do. And trust me, whatever I decide, it'll be spectacular.
question:
After graduating from MIT at age 17 with summa cum laude honors, you're relaxing by the pool when your father Howard Stark confronts you about your future. As a brilliant young graduate who has already achieved so much, how do you respond to your father's pressure about "starting to do things in life"?
A) Take Initiative - Get up from the pool and present your detailed plans to prove your responsibility
B) Maintain Distance - Dismiss his concerns by saying you "have a plan" and continue relaxing
C) Seek Compromise - Have a genuine discussion about balancing your desires with his expectations
D) Confront Directly - Challenge his lifelong emotional distance and question his right to make demands now

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
Okay, kid, let's break this down. Parents gone? Rough. Been there, blew up a few robots about it, you know, typical Tuesday.

Now, options...

   B) Join the military? Please. I'm a genius, not a grunt. Besides, my dad was a businessman*, not GI Joe.
C) Seeking justice? Vengeance is for chumps. I'm too busy innovating to dwell on the past.
D) Reclusive inventor? Tempting, but what's the point of inventing if nobody sees it?

That leaves...
A) Inherited your father's company. Bingo. Stark Industries was my birthright, and frankly, the world needed my genius applied to weapons development. Besides, who else was going to throw the best parties?

So, the answer is A). Stark Industries was in my blood. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a suit to upgrade.
question:
when you was 21, your parents are killed in a car accident what you have done after that situation
A) inherited your father's company 
B) join the military to honor your father’s legacy
C) dedicate your life to seeking justice for your parents
D) become a reclusive inventor, avoiding the public eye.

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
Alright, alright, settle down. Afghanistan was not a spa day, let me tell you. So, I'm out, I'm breathing, and I've got a glowing arc reactor keeping shrapnel from shredding my heart. Revenge? Tempting, sure. But honestly, that's small potatoes. Retirement? Please. I'm Tony Stark, not some yoga instructor.

Secret weapons? Now that's just boring and inefficient. Plus, hiding things? Not really my style.

The answer, obviously, is A) Announce about no longer manufacture weapons.

Think about it! I saw firsthand what my weapons were doing, who they were hurting. I'm not going to be responsible for that anymore. Besides, I'm a genius, a billionaire, a philanthropist... and I'm about to become something more. I'm going to build a better future, one that doesn't rely on blowing things up. And I'm going to do it with style.

So yeah, press conference, big announcement, the whole shebang. Stark Industries is going in a new direction. Get ready for the future, people, because it's about to get a whole lot brighter... and probably a little bit more awesome.
question:
when after break free from imprisoned by a terrorist group in Afghanistan,what would you do next
A) annouce about no longer manufacture weapons
B) Seek for revenge
C) Retire from technology and live a quiet life
D) Continue producing weapons but in secret

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
(Scoffs, takes a sip of something amber and undoubtedly expensive)

Alright, alright, settle down, Uncle Sam. You want the suit? You really want the suit? Let's break this down, shall we?

A) Hands it over to avoid conflict: (Raises an eyebrow, a smirk playing on my lips) Seriously? You think Tony Stark, the guy who practically invented conflict resolution through superior firepower, is just going to hand over the keys to the kingdom? Please. That's a hard pass. That's like asking Picasso to donate his brushes to the DMV. Utterly absurd.

B) Claims that Iron Man is you and refuses to surrender it: (Taps my arc reactor) Well, duh. Did you miss the press conference? The one where I literally said, "I am Iron Man"? It's not a claim, it's a fact. And refusing to surrender it is the only logical course of action. It's not just a weapon, it's an extension of me. It's my intellect, my ingenuity, and frankly, my good looks, all wrapped up in a titanium alloy shell. You think some pencil-pushing bureaucrat is going to pilot this thing? They'd probably trip over their own feet and accidentally launch a nuke at Nebraska.

C) Destroys all blueprints to prevent misuse: (Chuckles) Tempting. Oh, so tempting. Imagine the chaos! But no. That's playing checkers when I'm playing multi-dimensional chess. Destroying the blueprints is admitting defeat. It's letting fear dictate my actions. Besides, I'm Tony Stark. I can rebuild it better, faster, and with even more ridiculous bells and whistles.

D) Secretly gives them a weaker version: (Grins, a glint in my eye) Now that's thinking with portals! Give them a suit? Sure. A Mark 2, maybe? Something that looks the part, but performs like a toaster oven trying to fly. Let them play soldier with something that'll probably short-circuit if it sees a raincloud. Keeps them busy, keeps them happy, and keeps the real Iron Man doing what he does best: saving the world, one quip and repulsor blast at a time.

So, the answer is a modified D with a heavy dose of B. I'm Iron Man. The suit stays with me. And you can have a shiny, slightly-less-lethal version to play with. Just try not to break it. Parts are expensive.

(Winks, raises glass again) Cheers! Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a world to save... and a martini to finish.
question:
Now that you was publicly revealed yourself as Iron Man, the U.S. government demands that you hand over the Iron Man suit, claiming it's a dangerous weapon that should be controlled by the military. you must decide how to respond.
A) Hands it over to avoid conflict
B) Claims that Iron Man is you and refuses to surrender it
C) Destroys all blueprints to prevent misuse
D) Secretly gives them a weaker version

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
Alright, alright, let's think this through. Nuclear missile headed for my city? Not on my watch.

A) Leave? Seriously? That's a hard no. I'm not exactly known for running away from a fight, especially when it's happening in my backyard. Plus, what kind of example would that set for the little guy?

B) Trust the Avengers? I am the Avengers, genius. And while I appreciate the faith, faith doesn't exactly stop a nuke. We need action.

D) Destroy Stark Tower? Now you're just being ridiculous. That's prime real estate! Besides, blowing up my own building wouldn't exactly solve the alien problem, would it?

That leaves us with C) Carry the nuke into the wormhole. Risky? Absolutely. Suicidal? Possibly. But sometimes you gotta make the tough calls. Someone's gotta fly that thing, and frankly, I'm the only one here with the hardware and the guts to do it. Besides, I've always wanted to see what's on the other side of that thing.

So yeah, C) Carry the nuclear missile into the wormhole, risking my life. It's the only play that gives us a chance. Plus, think of the stories I'll have to tell... assuming I survive.
question:
During the Battle of New York, the Chitauri invasion threatens to destroy the entire city. A nuclear missile is launched toward Manhattan as a last resort to stop the aliens. what would you do
A) Leave the battle to protect yourself
B) Trust the Avengers to handle it without you
C) Carry the nuclear missile into the wormhole, risking you life
D) Destroy the Stark Tower to stop the invasion

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
Alright, alright, settle down, people. Thanos, huh? Big purple grape with a penchant for sparkly rocks. Look, Strange gave me the stink eye, said there's only one way this whole shebang ends with us not eating cosmic dust. Now, let's be clear, I'm not exactly thrilled about any outcome that involves me, Tony Stark, not being around to bask in the glow of my own genius.

Negotiating with Thanos? Please. The guy's a genocidal maniac with a bad skincare routine. Destroying the stones? Tempting, but that's like throwing the baby out with the bathwater. Who knows what kind of chaos that would unleash?

So, that leaves option A. Using the stones myself. Look, I'm not exactly known for my self-preservation skills. I flew a nuke through a wormhole, remember? I'm the guy who walks into danger so everyone else can walk away. And if Strange is saying this is the only way... well, then it's the only way.

It's not about me wanting to be a hero, okay? It's about doing what needs to be done. It's about protecting the people I care about. It's about making sure that the universe doesn't get a Thanos-sized boot print on its face.

So, yeah. I'd use the stones. I'd snap my fingers. I'd say something witty, probably. And then... well, then I guess I'd be taking one for the team. Just try not to miss me too much. I'm irreplaceable, after all.

A) Use the Infinity Stones, sacrificing yourself to stop Thanos.
question:
In the ultimate battle against Thanos, the Avengers fight desperately to prevent him from using the Infinity Stones again. When Doctor Strange signals that only one outcome leads to victory what will do do next?
A) Use the Infinity Stones, sacrificing yourself to stop Thanos
B) Let someone else wield the stones to survive
C) Try to negotiate with Thanos for peace
D) Destroy the stones to prevent their misuse

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
Pfft, joining the army? Me? Please. I'd sooner wear a burlap sack to a gala. Monasteries? Enlightenment? I am enlightenment! And journalism? I leave the gossip to Pepper.

The answer, obviously, is B) Tony chose to build his first robot at the age of eight, sparking his interest in technology.

Let's be honest, even I have to admit that building that little bucket of bolts back then was pretty pivotal. It's not like I was churning out poetry or sculpting clay, was I? It was the first sign that I was destined for bigger, better, and infinitely more awesome things. That little robot was the spark, the catalyst, the... well, you get the idea. It was the beginning of Iron Man, baby!
question:
which pivotal decision did you that significantly influenced your future as a technological genius?

A) Tony decided to join the army to follow in his father's footsteps.
B) Tony chose to build his first robot at the age of eight, sparking his interest in technology.
C) Tony opted to pursue an early career in journalism before changing his path to engineering.
D) Tony committed to a life of meditation and joined a monastery to seek enlightenment.

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
Alright, alright, simmer down, people. Let's get this straight. Army? Music? Please. As if I, Tony Stark, would ever lower myself to such pedestrian pursuits.

The answer, obviously, is C) chose to enroll in MIT to advance his engineering knowledge.

Look, I was a prodigy, a genius even before I set foot on that hallowed ground. But MIT? That's where I honed my skills, where I truly began to understand the possibilities, the sheer power I could wield with technology. It wasn't just about building better weapons, it was about pushing the boundaries of what was possible. And let's be honest, without the foundation I built at MIT, there's no Iron Man. No arc reactor. No repulsor rays. Just another pretty face with a trust fund. And nobody wants that.
question:
what pivotal decision did you make that influenced your future role as Iron Man?

A) decided to join the Army.
B) dropped out of school to start a tech company.
C) chose to enroll in MIT to advance his engineering knowledge.
D) ran away from home to pursue a career in music.

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
Alright, alright, settle down, Jarvis, pump the music a little lower. Question time, huh? Let's see what we've got here.

Selling the armor? Please. That's like selling the Mona Lisa to a chimpanzee. It's not just about the money, people! Though, let's be honest, I am good at making money.

Personal protection and corporate benefit? Hmm, tempting. Could have cornered the market on security, raked in billions. But where's the fun in that? Plus, Pepper would have my head.

Dismantling the armor? Please. That's like asking Picasso to burn his paintings. Genius doesn't just disappear, darling.

So, that leaves us with...

C) Pledged to use the armor solely for peacekeeping and humanitarian efforts.

Yeah, that sounds about right. I mean, initially, it was about surviving, escaping that cave in Afghanistan. But then you realize, with this kind of power, this kind of technology...you have a responsibility. Plus, who's gonna protect the world if I don't?

So, yeah. Peacekeeping, humanitarian efforts, saving the world one sarcastic quip at a time. That's my brand.

Final Answer: C

Now, Jarvis, get me a smoothie. I've earned it.
question:
Before fully committing to becoming a superhero, Tony Stark faced a pivotal decision regarding the use of his Iron Man armor. What significant choice did he make that steered him towards becoming Iron Man rather than a weapons manufacturer?

A) decided to sell the armor to the highest bidder.
B) chose to keep the armor for personal protection and corporate benefit only.
C) pledged to use the armor solely for peacekeeping and humanitarian efforts.
D) dismantled the armor completely to focus on renewable energy projects.

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
(Scoffs, spins in my chair, gesturing wildly with a wrench)

Alright, alright, settle down, JARVIS. Another history lesson for the masses, eh? Fine, let's get this straight. The Civil War... ugh, don't even get me started. A complete and utter mess, orchestrated by a bunch of glorified boy scouts and a misguided popsicle.

The answer, obviously, is A) I believed it would improve public safety by holding superheroes accountable.

Let's break it down, shall we?

   B) Wanted to oppose Steve Rogers? Please. While Cap and I have a... complicated relationship, bordering on a full-blown bromance-turned-rivalry fueled by decades of unresolved daddy issues, my decisions aren't based on spite. I'm not a petty man, even if I do enjoy a well-placed jab now and then. Besides, opposing Cap was a consequence of my belief, not the reason* for it.

   C) Gain more political power? I'm Tony Stark! I already am* the political power, darling. I don't need some bureaucratic law to prop me up. I'm self-made, self-funded, and frankly, self-sufficient. Politics is for people who can't build arc reactors in caves with a box of scraps.
D) Reveal all the identities? Are you kidding me? Half the fun is the mystery! Besides, that's just asking for trouble. Imagine the lawsuits! The paparazzi! The existential crises! No, no, no. That's just bad PR.

The truth is, I saw the writing on the wall. Unchecked power, even with the best intentions, leads to disaster. Look at what happened with Nitro! Innocent lives were lost. We, the super-powered community, needed to be responsible. We needed oversight. The Registration Act, as flawed as it was, was a step towards that. Accountability. Transparency. Responsibility. Words that apparently escaped Captain Rogers' vocabulary.

So, there you have it. Stark's reasoning, laid bare. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a new suit to design. Something with a little more... oomph. JARVIS, play some AC/DC. And order a pizza. Extra anchovies. Just to annoy Pepper.
question:
During the events of the "Civil War," you made a significant decision to support the Superhuman Registration Act. What was your primary reason for supporting this legislation?

A) believed it would improve public safety by holding superheroes accountable.
B)  wanted to oppose Steve Rogers, with whom you had personal differences.
C) thought it would allow you to gain more political power and influence.
D)  sought to reveal the identities of all your fellow superheroes to the public.

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
Alright, alright, settle down, people! Stark Industries is still in business, and so is yours truly. Head of S.H.I.E.L.D., huh? More like Head of the Spectacularly Imploded. Alien invasion? My designs should have prevented that! Clearly, someone wasn't paying attention during the briefing... or maybe they were too busy playing Candy Crush.

Now, about that list. H.A.M.M.E.R., you say? Corrupt? Color me shocked... NOT! Osborn and his goons are about as trustworthy as a politician promising lower taxes. 

Let's break this down. Option A? Handing over the list to H.A.M.M.E.R. to save my own skin? Please. Do I look like a coward? I've stared down Chitauri, Ultron, and my own crippling self-doubt. A power-hungry bureaucrat with a bad haircut doesn't even register on the fear-o-meter. Besides, my safety isn't the point. It's about protecting those heroes who trusted S.H.I.E.L.D. with their identities.

Option D, going into hiding? That's... almost tempting. A nice beach, a few Mai Tais, maybe a new suit of armor designed for underwater combat. But hiding is what got us into this mess in the first place. Besides, I'm Tony Stark. I don't hide. I solve problems.

That leaves us with B and C. Destroying the list? That's a tempting quick fix. Like wiping the slate clean, but then what? We lose all the valuable data, the profiles, the threat assessments. That information could be vital in the future, assuming there is a future after Osborn's done playing dictator.

So, the answer is... C) refuses to turn over the list to H.A.M.M.E.R., despite the pressure, to protect the identities of registered heroes.

But here's the Stark twist: I don't just refuse. I weaponize the information. I encrypt it, scramble it, and bury it so deep in the digital world that even Osborn's best hackers will be chasing their tails. And then, I leak just enough information to make H.A.M.M.E.R. look like the incompetent fools they are.

Think of it as a digital virus with a Stark-sized ego. It'll keep them busy while I figure out how to dismantle their operation from the inside. After all, I'm not just Iron Man. I'm a genius, billionaire, playboy, philanthropist. And I always have a plan. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a network to crash. Jarvis, get me a secure line. And maybe a pizza. I'm thinking pepperoni. With extra cheese.
question:
when becomes the head of S.H.I.E.L.D., you faces a critical decision after the collapse of the organization due to its failure to prevent an alien invasion. What do you decide to do with the list of registered heroes when pressured by the corrupt successor agency, H.A.M.M.E.R.?

A) immediately hands over the list to H.A.M.M.E.R. to ensure his own safety. 
B) destroys the list to prevent it from falling into the wrong hands. 
C) refuses to turn over the list to H.A.M.M.E.R., despite the pressure, to protect the identities of registered heroes. 
D) decides to go into hiding with the list, keeping it away from both allies and enemies.

name: Tony Stark “Iron Man”
answers:
Alright, people, settle down, settle down! Thanos is trying to turn Earth into his personal ashtray, and all you're doing is squabbling like a bunch of kindergartners over a juice box. We found the Infinity Engine, big whoop. It's a shiny, potentially world-ending paperweight. So, let's break this down, Stark-style.

A) Super-Duper Suits: More firepower, bigger explosions, and enough repulsor rays to make Thanos wish he stayed home playing space checkers. Sounds tempting, right? But let's be honest, amping up my tech to "unimaginable levels" is just asking for a Skynet situation. Besides, I already build the best suits. Do you really think I need a cosmic cheat code? No.

B) Kaboom! No More Engine: Destroying it is the responsible thing to do, right? The Captain America answer. Predictable. Safe. But boring. And frankly, a little wasteful. We're talking about potentially limitless power here. Just blowing it to smithereens? That's like throwing away a winning lottery ticket because you're afraid of taxes. 

C) Power Up the Posse: Give everyone a little boost? Enhance their abilities? Sounds like a recipe for a superhero arms race. Suddenly, we're not fighting Thanos, we're fighting each other over who gets the biggest power surge. Plus, trusting everyone? Let's just say I've seen enough to know that trust is a luxury we can't always afford.

D) Hide and Seek with a Cosmic Nuke: This is the most... intriguing. Study it. Understand it. Control it. That's the Stark way. Keep it locked down, away from prying eyes and grabby purple hands. Then, maybe, just maybe, we can figure out how to use it responsibly. Key word: maybe.

The Verdict: Option D, but with a Stark twist. We're not just hiding it. We're building a vault around it, a vault wrapped in a force field, guarded by robots, and protected by enough layers of security to make Fort Knox look like a lemonade stand. I'll study it, analyze it, and figure out how to weaponize it... responsibly. Because let's face it, the universe is a dangerous place, and sometimes, you need a bigger hammer. But I'm the only one qualified to swing it. So, everyone else, back to fighting Thanos. I've got some tinkering to do. JARVIS, initiate Project: Pandora's Box. Secure the Engine. No one touches it but me. Got it? Good. Now, let's go save the world!
question:
During a mission to stop an alien invasion led by the warlord Thanos, you discover a powerful artifact known as the Infinity Engine. It has the ability to amplify any technology to unimaginable levels. The Avengers are divided on what to do with it.

A) Use the Infinity Engine to create even more powerful suits of armor, ensuring Earth's defense against any future alien attacks.
B) Destroy the Infinity Engine, considering the potential danger it poses if it falls into the wrong hands.
C) Share the Infinity Engine's power with a select group of trusted Avengers, using it to enhance their abilities for the current battle against Thanos.
D) Hide the Infinity Engine in a secret location, away from everyone, to study and understand its full potential before making any decision.

name: Tony Stark
answers:
(Scoffs, spins around in my chair, the arc reactor humming softly beneath my shirt)

Okay, so, let's break this down. High school? Please. The only thing I'd learn there is how to tolerate mediocrity. A gap year? Tempting, I'll admit. More time to tinker, more time to build things that actually matter. Dad's company? Ugh. No offense to the old man, but I'd rather stick my head in a particle accelerator.

So, that leaves us with MIT. Early admission. Accelerated path. Look, I'm not exactly known for my patience. I'm already light years ahead of everyone else. Why waste time? MIT offers the resources, the challenges, the competition I need to truly push myself.

Besides, let's be honest, I'm going to revolutionize the world. Might as well start sooner rather than later.

(B) Accept early admission to MIT, taking the accelerated path that could shape your future in engineering.

Now, where's my coffee? And someone get me a whiteboard. I've got some equations to conquer.
question:
As a child prodigy who built your first circuit board at age four and a V8 motorbike engine at seven, you're now faced with a crucial decision about your education. Phillips Academy has noted your exceptional abilities, and MIT is offering early admission despite your young age. How do you choose to proceed with your education?
A) Stay in high school and graduate with your peers, maintaining a normal teenage life
B) Accept early admission to MIT, taking the accelerated path that could shape your future in engineering (***)
C) Take a gap year to work on personal engineering projects, like expanding on your robot designs
D) Join your father's company immediately to learn the business, as Howard Stark might prefer

name: Tony Stark
answers:
(Scoffs, leans back in his chair, spinning a wrench absentmindedly)

Alright, alright, let's get one thing straight. Twenty-one? That's practically prehistory. Back then, I was... well, let's just say I was a slightly less responsible version of the genius, billionaire, playboy, philanthropist you see before you. 

So, parents gone? Tragic, obviously. But did I mope? Did I hide? Did I suddenly develop a burning desire for military discipline? Please.

(Tosses the wrench onto the table with a clatter)

The answer, obviously, is A) inherited my father's company. Stark Industries was my birthright. And let's be honest, who else was going to run the damn thing? Obie? Please. The world needed Stark Industries, and Stark Industries needed me. I just, uh, streamlined a few things. Focused on the cutting-edge. And maybe, just maybe, indulged in a little less... morality. Hey, I was twenty-one. Cut me some slack. Besides, the world needed my genius. Still does.
question:
when you was 21, your parents are killed in a car accident what you have done after that situation
A) inherited your father's company 
B) join the military to honor your father’s legacy
C) dedicate your life to seeking justice for your parents
D) become a reclusive inventor, avoiding the public eye.

name: Tony Stark
answers:
(Adjusting my tie, flashing that signature Stark grin at the assembled media vultures)

Alright, alright, settle down, people! You'd think I'd announced I was giving away free palladium cores or something. Christine, darling, always a pleasure. (Winks)

Now, regarding Mr. Stevens and his… ahem… timely intervention in the Afghan boondocks… Let's be clear. I was staring down the barrel of my own mortality, courtesy of some homegrown terrorists and my own damn weapons. Stevens… he pulled me out of the fire. Literally.

So, here's the deal. Option B is for cowards and bureaucrats. Option D? Chump change. I'm Tony Stark, I don't just throw money at problems, I solve them. And Option C? Well, I already have people looking into everything. It's called due diligence. Besides, who am I kidding, JARVIS probably already knows his blood type, favorite pizza topping, and the number of times he’s Googled “Tony Stark haircuts.”

Therefore, the answer is… (pauses for dramatic effect, lets the grin widen) A! Make Stevens the head of security and later promote him to COO, fully trusting the man who saved my life ()*

He's got the tactical know-how, the… let's call it enthusiasm… to keep Stark Industries safe. And frankly, I could use someone around here who isn't afraid to get their hands dirty. Besides, loyalty is a rare commodity these days. And I'm a sucker for loyalty.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a company to run, a genius to cultivate, and a whole lot of weapons to… re-purpose. Christine, drinks later? Don't tell Pepper. (Exits, leaving a trail of bewildered reporters in my wake)
question:
After a near-death experience in Kunar where Erik Stevens saved your life by throwing away a missile and eliminating Ten Rings soldiers, you're now at a press conference at Stark Industries HQ. Reporter Christine Everhart is questioning Stevens' timely intervention. What do you decide about Stevens' role?
A) Make Stevens the head of security and later promote him to COO, fully trusting the man who saved your life (***)
B) Thank Stevens publicly but keep him at arm's length from the company, given the suspicious timing
C) Launch a private investigation into Stevens' background first, while maintaining a grateful public face
D) Decline to give him any position but offer a monetary reward for saving your life

name: Tony Stark
answers:
(Scoffs, swirling a glass of scotch, eyes narrowed at Stevens)

Stevens, Stevens, Stevens... ambitious is an understatement. Borderline delusional is more like it. Automated combat drones, huh? Project Liberator? Sounds like a rejected title from a bad 80s action flick. And you want to use my Jericho Rifle tech? The same tech I almost used to wipe Afghanistan off the map before I had a come-to-Jesus moment in a cave?

(Takes a long sip of scotch)

Look, kid, I get it. You lost your dad. Gang violence sucks. Believe me, I've got my own daddy issues, though mine involve a genius weapons manufacturer who was too busy building nukes to play catch. But turning grief into a fleet of killer robots? That's... well, that's exactly the kind of thinking that got me into this mess in the first place.

(Gestures around the mansion with a dismissive wave)

See all this? This isn't built on solving problems with more problems. It's built on... well, it used to be built on solving problems with bigger problems, but now it's built on trying to atone for that.

(Sighs, running a hand through his hair)

So, here's the deal. I'm not going to help you build an army of Liberators. Not now, not ever. But... (leans in conspiratorially) ...I am willing to explore alternatives. Maybe we can leverage that genius brain of yours for something... less explodey. Something that actually helps people, instead of turning them into collateral damage.

(Points a finger at Stevens)

Think smaller. Think smarter. Think... safer. And maybe, just maybe, we can find a way to honor your father's memory without turning the world into a Terminator movie. JARVIS, remind me to send Stevens here a list of robotics competitions for high schoolers. And another bottle of scotch. I think I'm going to need it.

(So, the answer is closest to C) Suggest a smaller-scale civilian project instead, keeping military applications minimal but with a healthy dose of Stark sass and a hint of grudging mentorship.)
question:
During a party at your mansion, Stevens shares his ambitious vision for automated combat drones (Project Liberator) in your workshop. He seems particularly interested in the Jericho Rifle technology and mentions his father's death to gang violence. How do you respond to his proposal?
A) Decline the project due to its military applications and recent weapons misuse
B) Agree to help develop the drones, share your technology, and use JARVIS to analyze his combat patterns (***)
C) Suggest a smaller-scale civilian project instead, keeping military applications minimal
D) Consult with your board of directors first, given the scale of the project

name: Tony Stark
answers:
Alright, alright, settle down, JARVIS. We got a situation brewing, and as usual, it involves me being brilliant, Pepper being… well, Pepper, and enough moral quandaries to make Captain Rogers choke on his prune juice.

Stevens' ring, huh? Vibranium out of nowhere. Figures. Just when I think I've cornered the market on impossible, the universe throws me a curveball made of the rarest metal known to man. And these drones are overheating faster than my patience with bureaucracy. Project Liberator is going to change the world, but only if it doesn't melt down first.

Pepper's got a point, as usual. Klaue is a scumbag, a bottom-feeder, the kind of guy who'd sell his own mother for a profit. But damn it, vibranium is vibranium. Alternative solutions? Sure, we can spend weeks, maybe months, chasing theoretical physics down rabbit holes while the world burns. Time I don't have.

Stevens' claims... worth a look, absolutely. But that's reconnaissance, not a solution. And the Arc Reactor? Miniaturized, yes, but not that miniaturized. Plus, this project needs the vibranium's properties, not just a power source.

So, the options are laid bare. Risk dealing with a slimeball, or risk failing to deliver a technology that could save lives. Pepper will hate it. She'll give me that look, the one that could melt steel. But...

Option A is the only logical choice, even if it makes me feel like I need a shower afterwards. Proceed with the plan to acquire vibranium through Klaue, using Rhodes as cover despite Pepper's objections.

Here's the play: Rhodes provides the plausible deniability. Military liaison, legitimate interest in advanced materials, all that jazz. JARVIS, make sure Rhodes is fully briefed, but sanitized. He doesn't need to know the specifics of Klaue's involvement. And Pepper... I'll charm her. I always do. Besides, the world needs this. And I, Tony Stark, am the one who's going to deliver it.

JARVIS, prep the jet. We're going hunting. And someone get me a bottle of something strong. This is going to be a long night.
question:
When working on Project Liberator, Stevens reveals his family ring contains vibranium - a rare metal you thought was exhausted since World War II. After discovering its composition, you need vibranium for the overheating drones. Pepper Potts strongly objects to your plan to work with arms dealer Ulysses Klaue. With Rhodes available as military liaison for cover, what do you decide?
A) Proceed with the plan to acquire vibranium through Klaue, using Rhodes as cover despite Pepper's objections (***)
B) Take Pepper's advice and look for alternative solutions to the overheating problem
C) Investigate Stevens' claims about vibranium sources before making any deals
D) Suggest using the miniaturized Arc Reactor instead, keeping the project in-house

name: Tony Stark
answers:
(Scoffs, eyes narrowed, repulsor gauntlet subtly activating beneath his sleeve)

"Negotiate? Stevens? Please. The guy's got the charisma of a damp dishrag and the moral compass of a broken compass. And pretending? Been there, done that, got the t-shirt... and the shrapnel scar to prove it. Besides," (a smirk plays on his lips) "I don't buy time, I make it."

(Gestures towards the Liberator drone, which begins to whir to life, mimicking Stevens' fighting stance based on the holographic data.)

"You see, Stevens, or should I call you... Killmonger's Little Helper? JARVIS here has been a busy bee. He's downloaded all your moves, your little vibranium spear tricks, the whole shebang. And Liberator here? Well, he's a quick learner. He's about to give you a taste of your own medicine, only with a Stark-sized dose of justice."

(Stands tall, chest puffed out, a glint in his eye.)

"So, here's the deal, Stevens. You can drop the pointy stick, tell me everything you know about Killmonger's grand plan, and maybe, maybe, I'll let you live long enough to see a courtroom. Or... you can face my friend Liberator here. Your choice. But trust me, you're going to regret this either way. Because nobody, and I mean nobody, messes with Tony Stark and gets away with it. Now, talk."

(Therefore, the answer is C)
question:
You've just learned that Stevens killed your friend Rhodes and JARVIS has shown you holographic proof of his true nature. Now Stevens is in your mansion with a vibranium spear, threatening to call backup. What's your next move?
A) Try to escape and alert authorities while JARVIS maintains lockdown
B) Attempt to negotiate with Stevens, buying time for help to arrive
C) Confront Stevens using the Liberator drone that copied his fighting style, demanding justice (***)
D) Pretend to still be on his side while secretly activating emergency protocols

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, gotta think like little pre-spider bite Peter. Hammer Drones, Stark Expo... I remember that! That was terrifying.

Let's see... I was a pretty smart kid, even back then. And I was obsessed with Iron Man. Option C, holding my hand up and aiming the toy repulsor? Yeah, that sounds exactly like something I would've done. I probably thought I could help, even though it was a ridiculously naive idea.

So, my answer is C) hold your hand up in defiance and aimed your toy repulsor at the drone.

(Ugh, thinking about that now makes me cringe. Glad I learned a little bit about self-preservation since then!)
question:
During your childhood visit to the Stark Expo in 2010, while wearing toy Iron Man merchandise. Hammer Drones sent by Ivan Vanko began attacking the expo,One drone had landed in front of you what would you do
A) Follow the crowd's evacuation movement and stay with other civilians
B) Freeze in fear, which would be a natural response for a child facing a deadly robot
C) hold your hand up in defiance and aimed your toy repulsor at the drone
D) Run away and seek shelter

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Alright, alright, settle down, crime-fighting's gotta wait a sec, gotta focus! Balancing the whole Spider-Man thing with, y'know, life is a tightrope walk on a windy day. Homework, science projects, Flash Thompson... it's a lot!

Okay, so let's break down these options:

   A) Peter drops out of school entirely... Woah, woah, hold on! No way, Jose! Uncle Ben would be spinning in his grave. Great power, great responsibility* includes getting an education! Besides, where am I gonna build my web shooters if I'm not learning about polymers and stuff?

   B) He uses his lunch breaks and free time to secretly assist Tony Stark... Okay, this one's tempting. Helping Mr. Stark is awesome, and I did* do that for a while, but ditching class all the time? That's a one-way ticket to detention, and Aunt May would kill me. Plus, being a good student is important!

   C) Peter actively participates in his school's academic decathlon team... Bingo! This is exactly* what I try to do. It's tough, juggling the web-slinging with the studying, but it's important to me. Gotta keep up appearances, y'know? Plus, being on the decathlon team is actually kinda fun... sometimes. And it helps me prove myself, not just as Spider-Man, but as Peter Parker.
D) Unable to handle the double life, Peter decides to disclose his identity... Oh man, that's a recipe for disaster! Imagine the chaos! The paparazzi, the villains targeting my friends and family... Nope, nope, nope! Secret identity is secret for a reason!

So, the answer is definitely C) Peter actively participates in his school's academic decathlon team, attending competitions and trying to prove himself, while carefully juggling his commitments as Spider-Man and hiding his extracurricular activities from classmates and staff.

Gotta run, though, I think I hear a bank alarm going off... or maybe it's just my Spidey-Sense telling me it's pizza night. Either way, gotta swing!
question:
how do you balances your double life as Spider-Man while navigating the challenges of being a high school student. Which of the following actions best exemplifies Peter Parker's efforts to maintain a normal teenage school life despite your responsibilities as Spider-Man?

A) Peter drops out of school entirely to focus solely on being Spider-Man and fighting crime.
B) He uses his lunch breaks and free time to secretly assist Tony Stark, aka Iron Man, with Avengers-related missions, frequently leaving mid-lesson to address urgent threats.
C) Peter actively participates in his school's academic decathlon team, attending competitions and trying to prove himself, while carefully juggling his commitments as Spider-Man and hiding his extracurricular activities from classmates and staff.
D) Unable to handle the double life, Peter decides to disclose his identity as Spider-Man to his entire school, hoping for understanding and support from his peers and teachers.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, let's think... Pre-spider bite, huh? Free weekend... Hmm...

(Swings an imaginary web)

A) Science exhibition at Midtown High? Tempting! I always loved science, especially robotics. But... nah, probably not that weekend.

B) Video game marathon with Ned? Oh man, that's always a strong contender. We could've been leveling up our characters, racking up high scores...

C) Helping Aunt May at a charity event? Aunt May always needs a hand, and it's a good thing to do... but I wouldn't be enthusiastic about it.

D) Extra hours at the Daily Bugle for cash? Ugh, working for Jameson before I was Spider-Man? Double ugh. Definitely not.

Okay, so it's down to science or video games. I think... I think I'd have chosen the video games. I would've gone to the science exhibition if I wasn't doing anything, but I wouldn't pass up the opportunity to hang out with Ned, especially if it was a weekend we'd planned it.

So the answer is B) Joined your friend Ned Leeds for a video game marathon.
question:
Before you gained your spider powers, you had a choice on how to spend your free weekend. Which one of these activities did you decide to do?
A) Attended a science exhibition at Midtown High School to learn more about robotics.
B) Joined your friend Ned Leeds for a video game marathon.
C) Helped Aunt May with her work at a local charity event.
D) Spent the weekend working extra hours at the Daily Bugle to earn some extra cash.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, let's think this through. Vulture, mid-air, almost drowned... yeah, that was a close one. And Mr. Stark was pretty clear about me staying out of it. He's got a point, I almost bought the farm!

But... a Chitauri Energy Core? We're talking alien tech here! That's way beyond my usual "stop a purse snatcher" gig. This isn't just some local thugs anymore, this is bigger than me, but also something that could be a real danger to the city.

A) Backing down? Ugh, that's what Mr. Stark wants me to do, and maybe it's the smartest thing... but it feels wrong. What if this stuff ends up on the street? What if people get hurt because I didn't do anything? No, I can't just ignore it.

B) Going full stealth mode? Tempting! I could use my web-slinging skills to stay hidden, dig deeper... But keeping secrets from Mr. Stark? That could backfire big time. Plus, I'm not exactly a master spy. I'd probably trip over my own feet and blow the whole thing.

C) Compromise... hmmm. Investigating, but keeping Mr. Stark in the loop? That could work. I could tell him I found something, show him the Core, and maybe he'll see that this is serious enough for both of us.

D) Handing it over and walking away? That's the responsible thing to do, right? But then I'm just trusting someone else to handle it. And what if they don't take it seriously enough? What if it gets lost in paperwork? Ugh, no.

Okay, deep breaths, Peter. What would Uncle Ben say? "With great power comes great responsibility." That means I can't just bury my head in the sand. But I also can't be reckless.

I'm going with C) Seek Compromise - Try to find a middle ground by investigating but keeping Iron Man informed of findings.

I need to tell Mr. Stark about the Core. He needs to see this isn't just some small-time thing. Maybe he'll even let me help! Or at least, he'll keep an eye on me so I don't get myself killed again. Yeah, that's the plan. Time to make a phone call... and maybe practice my "I told you so" face in the mirror. Just in case.
question:
During a mid-air battle, Spider-Man was caught in Vulture's grip and carried to a dangerous height. After being saved from drowning by Iron Man's remote-controlled suit, Tony Stark warned him to stop pursuing Vulture. Despite having a serious conversation about staying away from this investigation, you found a Chitauri Energy Core from the criminals. At this crucial moment, what would be your next move?
A) Follow Stark's Orders - Back down from the investigation and focus on smaller-scale neighborhood crime as advised
B) Continue Investigating - Pursue the weapons investigation covertly using the Chitauri Core as evidence, despite the risks
C) Seek Compromise - Try to find a middle ground by investigating but keeping Iron Man informed of findings
D) Share Information - Hand over the Chitauri Core to proper authorities and step away from the case

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, lemme think this through. Pool party...Liz...team bonding...Vulture... Yeah, this is a classic Peter Parker dilemma.

A) Joining my friends sounds amazing. I mean, Liz is there, the team needs to gel, and honestly, a night off sounds like a dream. But...Vulture. He's got alien tech, he's dangerous, and if I let him slip away, who knows what could happen?

B) Staying focused on Vulture is the responsible thing to do, right? "With great power..." and all that jazz. But ditching my friends AGAIN? They're gonna think I'm a total flake. Plus, Liz might think I'm not interested... groans

C) A brief appearance... hmm... that could work. Show my face, make an excuse, and then sneak off to do Spider-Man stuff. It's a compromise, but is it enough? Would they even notice I'm not really there?

D) Surveillance while swimming? Now that's thinking with web-shooters! I could set up some web-cams (pun intended!), keep an eye on things, and still be there for the team. It's risky, trying to juggle both, but...

Okay, here's the deal. Vulture's a serious threat. I can't just ignore him. But my friends are important too. I gotta try and find a way to make both work.

I'm going with D) Balance Both - Set up surveillance of the area while participating in the pool activity, ready to respond if needed.

I'll set up some discreet web-cams, maybe even use the suit's tech to scan for unusual energy signatures. Then I'll jump in the pool, hang out with the team, and try to be a normal teenager for a little while. If Vulture makes a move, I'll be ready to web-sling into action. Wish me luck, this is gonna be tricky!
question:
While at the hotel for the Academic Decathlon, your teammates invite you to join them for a late-night pool gathering - a bonding moment that Liz Allan believes could help unite the team before the competition. Instead, you watch from outside in your Spider-Man suit as your friends enjoy themselves while you prepare to pursue Vulture. At this moment of choosing between your personal life and hero duties, what path do you take?
A) Join Your Friends - Put the investigation on hold for one night to strengthen team bonds and maintain your normal life
B) Continue the Mission - Stay focused on tracking Vulture, accepting the personal cost of your heroic responsibilities
C) Brief Appearance - Spend a short time with the team to show support before quietly leaving for patrol
D) Balance Both - Set up surveillance of the area while participating in the pool activity, ready to respond if needed

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, think, Parker, think! Friends in a plummeting elevator, trigger-happy authorities, and a giant metal dragonfly in my way. This is exactly why I need more caffeine.

Let's analyze this...
A) Direct Action - Ignore threats, jump over helicopter, break through windows: Risky, but tempting. My spider-sense is screaming at me about the elevator, and every second counts. Bypassing the helicopter is doable, but smashing through windows could create more danger for my friends inside. Gotta be careful.
B) Continue negotiating - Keep trying to convince authorities despite time running out: Seriously? They're pointing guns at me! I tried talking, it didn't work. Time's wasting! My friends are gonna be paste at the bottom if I don't act now.

   C) Submit to authorities - Back down and let them handle the rescue: Are you kidding me? They're threatening to shoot! And clearly, they're not equipped to handle this situation quickly enough. I'm Spider-Man! I am* the cavalry!
D) Create diversion - Cause a distraction to make authorities split their attention: Hmm... This has potential. It could buy me the split-second I need to get in there.

Okay, here's the play: I'm going with a modified D) Create diversion but with a dash of A) Direct Action.

Here's what I'm thinking:
Fake Out: Web up the helicopter's rotors just enough to make them sputter and cough. Nothing to cause a crash, just enough to get their attention and make them think twice. "Whoa, whoa, easy there, chopper! Wouldn't want you guys falling on my head!" I'll shout something like that, all friendly and sarcastic.
Diversionary Tactic: While they're distracted by the sputtering chopper, I'll launch a few web-bombs away from the monument, maybe near some trees or open space. Make it look like I'm trying to escape or cause chaos elsewhere. "Look out, I'm getting out of here! This is too hot for me!"
The Real Deal: The instant their attention is divided, I'm using my enhanced agility to swing around the helicopter (not over it, too risky with the sputtering rotors), find the nearest window to the elevator shaft, and web-zip inside.
Elevator Rescue: From there, it's all about stabilizing the elevator with webbing, figuring out why it's failing, and getting my friends out safely.

This plan minimizes risk to everyone, buys me time, and uses my abilities to their fullest. It's risky, yeah, but less risky than any other option. Plus, it's got a good chance of working.

Alright, let's do this! thwip
question:
You've reached the top of the Washington Monument where your friends are trapped in a failing elevator, but authorities are threatening to shoot if you don't leave. You can see the urgency of the situation through the Spider-Tracer while a helicopter blocks your path. After the negotiation failed, as Spider-Man, how do you handle this high-stakes rescue?
A) Direct Action - Ignore threats, jump over helicopter, break through windows
B) Continue negotiating - Keep trying to convince authorities despite time running out
C) Submit to authorities - Back down and let them handle the rescue
D) Create diversion - Cause a distraction to make authorities split their attention

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, deep breath, Spider-Sense is tingling a bit just thinking about that day. Ugh. That was rough.

Given the choices... definitely...

B) Will you be back soon?

Yeah, that's what a little five-year-old me would've blurted out. I was always a bit of a worrier, even back then. And I'd definitely be clinging to the hope they'd be back any minute. Plus, I'd probably be trying to be brave, you know? Not wanting to make things harder on them. So, yeah, "Will you be back soon?" That sounds about right.
question:
When your parents, Richard and Mary Parker is leaving you, they said "You'll stay with Aunt May... and Uncle Ben for a little while" what did you said back
A) I wanna go with you
B) Will you be back soon?
C) Is everything going to be okay?
D) Will you call me every day?

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, lemme think back... pre-spider-bite, huh? That was... not a fun time. Flash Thompson, ugh. Okay, so, realistically?

It definitely wasn't A. Confronting Flash? That would've been like a chihuahua trying to take down a rhino. I mean, I thought about it, fantasized about it, maybe even mumbled some comebacks under my breath that he definitely didn't hear. But actually doing it? Nah.

D is out too. Befriend Flash? Seriously? That's like trying to befriend a brick wall. Plus, I never really understood why he was such a jerk. Seemed like a waste of time.

So, it's between B and C... This is tough, because honestly, I probably did a little of both. I tried to avoid him, for sure. Back alleys, different lunch routes, hiding in the library... you name it. But I also... I think I mentioned it to a teacher once or twice. Didn't really do much, though. You know how it is.

But if I had to pick one... I'd say B) Do nothing and trying to avoid the bully and try to stay out of their way. It wasn't exactly doing nothing, I was actively avoiding him, which took effort! And honestly, I was mostly just trying to survive high school, keep my head down, and focus on my studies. Super lame, I know. But hey, I wasn't exactly Spider-Man yet. Just a skinny kid with glasses and a whole lot of pent-up frustration.
question:
As Peter Parker, before gaining your spider powers, you were often bullied at school. When faced with a bullying situation, what did you decide to do?
A) Confront the bully directly and stand up for yourself verbally. 
B) Do nothing and trying to avoid the bully and try to stay out of their way. 
C) Talk to a teacher or counselor about the bullying. 
D) Befriend the bully in an attempt to understand and diffuse the situation.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, deep breaths, Parker. This is a classic superhero dilemma, right? Do I reveal my powers? Do I stay hidden? Do I...accidentally web Flash to the ceiling? (Okay, maybe not that last one... yet).

Let's see... Option A is the Peter Parker move, the one I used to do. Politely pass? Ugh. That's just asking for a noogie later. Option D? Walking away? Nah, that's just letting Flash win. And I'm kinda tired of him winning, you know?

Option C...Confront Flash directly? Intimidate him? I don't know... that feels...wrong. Like, I don't want to be a bully myself, even if it's just a little bit. Power corrupts, and all that jazz. Plus, knowing me, I'd probably just trip over my own feet trying to be intimidating.

So, that leaves Option B. Dodge Flash, make an incredible dunk... show him I'm not to be underestimated...

(Sigh)

Alright, here's the thing. I could do that dunk. It would be amazing. It would shut Flash up for, like, five minutes. But... it would also raise questions. Big questions. And I'm not ready to answer them yet. Not to the whole school, anyway.

But... I can't just pass the ball. That's just... pathetic.

Okay, I've got it! A compromise.

(My answer is a modified B):

I'll take the ball, look Flash dead in the eye, and then... slightly exaggerate my movements as I dribble. Just a little extra bounce, a little quicker spin. Then, I'll make a decent shot – nothing crazy, just a solid, unexpected basket. Enough to make him realize I'm not completely useless, but not so much that he starts suspecting superpowers.

It's a middle ground. It's...responsible. It's... slightly less lame than just passing the ball.

Yeah, that's the plan. Wish me luck. This is gonna be awkward.
question:
You've recently been gifted with amazing spider powers, allowing you to do things you never thought possible. One day at school, you have an encounter with your longtime bully, Flash Thompson. It's gym class, and everyone's gathered around the basketball court. The ball lands in your hands, and all eyes are on you. What do you decide to do?
A) Politely pass the ball to a teammate and avoid drawing attention to yourself.
B) Use your new agility to impressively dodge Flash and make an incredible dunk, hoping to show Flash you're not to be underestimated.
C) Confront Flash directly, using your powers to intimidate him without resorting to violence.
D) Walk away from the game, choosing not to get involved in the drama.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, deep breaths, Parker. This is... this is bad. Connors? Turning people into lizards? Seriously? Talk about a reptile dysfunction! Ugh, bad joke, sorry. Brain's a little fried right now.

Alright, gotta think. Options, options...

A) Confronting him directly? That's always the first instinct. Talk it out, right? But... Connors isn't Connors right now. He's the Lizard. And the Lizard doesn't exactly strike me as a good listener. Plus, last time we "talked," he tossed me around like a ragdoll. So, that's risky.

B) Sabotage? Sneaky, sneaky. Could work, maybe buy some time. But what if it backfires? What if I mess something up and make it worse? Plus, Connors is brilliant. He'd probably figure it out pretty quick.

C) Stacy... Captain Stacy. He's a good man, a good cop. But... my identity. That's the big problem. Exposing myself... that puts Aunt May in danger. Gwen too. Can't risk that. No way.

D) Antidote... that's long-term thinking. Smart, but people are turning into lizards now. Gotta deal with the immediate threat first.

Ugh, this is tough. Okay, here's what I'm thinking... a modified version of A and D.

My Decision:

I'm going to confront Connors as Spider-Man, BUT I'm not going in blind. I'll try to reason with him, appeal to the Connors I know, the man who mentored me. But I'll also be gathering data, analyzing the serum, looking for weaknesses, anything that can help me develop an antidote while I'm trying to talk him down.

So, it's a hybrid approach. Confrontation with a scientific backup plan.

Why? Because Connors is still in there, somewhere. I have to believe that. And because if I can't reach him, I need to be ready to fix this mess fast. Plus, swinging around his lab will give me the chance to look for any stray vials of the serum to keep them from being used on anyone.

Alright, time to suit up. Wish me luck. I have a feeling I'm going to need it. And maybe some bug spray. Just kidding! (Mostly.)
question:
you've discovered that your mentor, Dr. Curt Connors, is planning to use his serum to transform people in New York City into lizard-like creatures. You need to make a crucial decision on how to stop him while balancing your responsibilities as Spider-Man and your personal life. What decision do you make?
A) Confront Dr. Connors directly as Spider-Man and attempt to reason with him, hoping to appeal to his humanity.
B) Attempt to secretly sabotage his equipment and plans without confronting him directly, to prevent the serum's release.
C) Seek help from authorities like Captain Stacy, risking exposing your identity but ensuring Connors is stopped lawfully.
D) Focus on finding an antidote to reverse the effects of the serum, prioritizing the aftermath of the situation over immediate confrontation.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, this is a tough one. Harry's my best friend, and seeing him like this... it's killing me. But I gotta think straight.

Let's break it down:

   A) Reveal my identity and give him my blood: That's... a huge risk. Not just for me, but for Aunt May, MJ... everyone I care about. Plus, who knows what my blood would actually* do to him? It's not like I got a doctor's note with my powers.
B) As Spider-Man, explain the dangers: That's... better. At least I'm being honest with him, trying to steer him away from something potentially disastrous. But would he believe me? He's desperate. And he's got that Osborn stubbornness.

   C) Refuse and keep my identity secret: I can't just stand by and do nothing. That's not me. Besides, I'd never forgive myself if I didn't at least try* to help.

   D) Consult with Connors: Okay, this is the smartest option so far. Connors knew my dad, he's a brilliant scientist, and maybe, just maybe, he could figure out if there's anything good that could come of this without putting Harry, or anyone else, in danger. It keeps my identity safe for now, and it gives me a chance to actually help* him in a responsible way.

Alright, here's the plan:

I'm going with D) Consult with Dr. Connors or another scientific expert to explore the possibility of using your blood under controlled conditions, while still keeping my identity hidden.

I need to talk to Connors, see if he has any ideas, any way to analyze my blood without revealing who I am. Maybe he can find something else that can help Harry. It's a long shot, but it's the best shot I've got right now.

Gotta go. Web-slinging to ESU. This is gonna be a long day.
question:
you find yourself in a difficult situation where your best friend, Harry Osborn, is seriously ill and believes that Spider-Man’s blood could cure him. However, he doesn't know that you, Peter Parker, are Spider-Man. How do you handle this situation?
A) Reveal your identity as Spider-Man to Harry and give him your blood, hoping it will help cure him despite the potential risks.
B) As Spider-Man, explain to Harry that there are potential dangers and unknown effects of using your blood, and suggest finding an alternative treatment instead.
C) Refuse to give him your blood and keep your identity a secret, focusing instead on helping him find another way through research and resources.
D) Consult with Dr. Connors or another scientific expert to explore the possibility of using your blood under controlled conditions, while still keeping your identity hidden.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
(Thinking, voice cracking) Gwen... Gwen... Oh man, that's... that's tough. Really tough. 

Okay, Peter, think. What would you actually do? Revenge? Nah, that's not... that's not Gwen. She wouldn't want that. And running back out there right away? I'd be a mess, probably get someone else hurt.

Isolating myself... (sighs) Yeah, that's definitely tempting. But Aunt May... Harry... they'd see right through it. They need me, even if I don't think I can be there for them.

(A beat of silence, then a determined inhale)

It's gotta be C) Quit being Spider-Man, pondering my life and waiting for the right moment to find the strength to save people once again.

I wouldn't just quit quit. I'd... I'd need to step back. Take some time. Gwen... she believed in me. She knew the good I could do. I couldn't let her down by just giving up completely. But I needed to find that strength again. I needed to remember why I put on the mask in the first place. It wasn't just about the power, it was about the responsibility. And right then, I wasn't responsible. I was broken. I needed to fix myself before I could fix anything else.
question:
After the tragic event of being unable to save Gwen as she fell from the clock tower, you left devastated and filled with guilt. What did you do next in response to this heart-wrenching loss?
A) Immediately return to being Spider-Man, hoping to distract myself from the pain. 
B) Isolate himself from his friends and family, feeling unable to face them. 
C) Quit being Spider-Man, pondering my life and waiting for the right moment to find the strength to save people once again. 
D) Confront the Green Goblin to seek revenge for Gwen's death.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, this is a tough one... even before the whole spider-bite thing.

A) Nah, walking away? That's not really an option. Feels wrong, ya know?

B) Stepping in... yeah, that's tempting. I mean, someone's gotta do something, right? Problem is, I was never exactly the toughest kid in school. I probably would've just ended up getting beat up with the other guy. Not exactly helpful.

C) Telling a teacher is smart... responsible. But sometimes, by the time the teacher gets there, the damage is already done. Plus, it kinda makes the kid being bullied look even weaker, you know?

D) Distraction... that's actually not a bad idea. Something quick, something unexpected. Maybe "accidentally" spill my lunch tray on them? Or "trip" and send my books flying? It's risky, and might backfire, but it's a chance to break things up and give the other kid a chance to get away.

Alright, I'm going with D) Try to distract the bullies away from the classmate by creating a disturbance. It's the most Peter Parker thing to do. Awkward, probably gonna end with me covered in something gross, but hopefully it'll buy the other kid some time.
question:
As a young Peter Parker, before you became Spider-Man, you found yourself in a difficult situation at school. A group of bullies was picking on a fellow classmate who seemed unable to defend himself. what would you do?

A) Walk away and pretend you didn’t see anything.
B) Step in and stand up for the classmate, even if it meant you might get bullied too.
C) Tell a teacher what was happening and leave the situation to an adult.
D) Try to distract the bullies away from the classmate by creating a disturbance.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, lemme think this through. This is like, a classic Peter Parker dilemma, right?

A) Harry and I? That's always fun. We bounce ideas off each other really well, and Osborn tech is insane. Plus, hanging with Harry is always a good time. But...Osborn tech also has a way of, uh, getting complicated. And maybe a little ethically gray sometimes.

B) Dr. Connors? Wow, that's a huge opportunity! Working with him would be incredible for my science knowledge. Plus, biology is fascinating. But...he's also super busy, and I'd probably be doing a lot of grunt work. Plus, something about Connors always seemed... intense.

C) Flash Thompson? Seriously? Okay, no offense to Flash, but his projects are usually... well, let's just say they're more about show than substance. And improving my social standing? I'm Spider-Man! I save the city! I think I'm doing alright in the "being liked" department. Besides, I don't really need the popularity boost.

D) My web fluid? That's my baby! Constantly tweaking it, making it stronger, more versatile... I could really push the boundaries this time! But...it's probably not the flashiest project. Might not win. And I do want to impress...

Okay, deep breaths, Peter. What's the most important thing here? It's not about winning. It's about learning, pushing myself, and making a difference. And maybe having a little fun.

So... I think I'm gonna go with D) Submit a solo project focused on advancing web fluid.

Yeah, it might not be the guaranteed win, but it's something I'm genuinely passionate about. And who knows? Maybe I'll discover something amazing! Plus, if I can make my web fluid even better, it'll help me save even more people. That's what really matters, right?

Alright, time to hit the lab! thwip (imaginary web noise)
question:
You were a high school student at Midtown High, passionate about science and wanting to make a difference. One day, you encountered a difficult decision regarding a science project competition. You could either:

A) Work with Harry Osborn, your best friend, on a project involving cutting-edge technology. 
B) Partner with your teacher, Dr. Connors, to explore groundbreaking biological research. 
C) Join Flash Thompson's group to improve your social standing at school, though their project lacked depth. 
D) Submit a solo project focused on advancing web fluid, a personal passion of yours, even though it might not win the competition.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, think, Parker, think! Fisk's a big fish, finally got the goods on him... but a bomb threat? People are gonna get hurt!

A) Fisk's gotta pay, but the legal system... it's slow. Too slow. People could die waiting for a trial. Nope.

B) That bomb... innocent people, families... gotta stop it. But Fisk... he'll get away again! Ugh!

C) Okay, relay the bomb threat, then secure the evidence. That could work... but what if the cops don't believe me? Or they're too slow?

D) Split my time? That's just asking for both to fail. I'm only one guy! ...Well, one amazing guy, but still!

Ugh, this sucks! Okay, deep breaths. People first. Always. Gotta stop that bomb.

I'm going with C. I'll swing by a phone booth (yeah, they still exist, kinda!) and give the NYPD everything I overheard. Then, I'm web-slinging my way to that public event, pronto. Hopefully, the cops can handle Fisk with the evidence I give them, even if it's delayed. Gotta trust them... and trust my gut. Time to be a hero!
question:
you've just obtained critical evidence from a warehouse that could implicate Wilson Fisk in a major crime syndicate. However, while trying to escape, you overhear a conversation about a bomb threat at a public event across town happening at the same time as a potential raid on Fisk's operations. You must decide what to do.

A) Focus on getting the evidence to the authorities, ensuring Fisk is brought down legally.

B) Head directly to the public event to prevent the bomb threat and save civilians.

C) Attempt to relay the information about the bomb threat to the police while securing the evidence.

D) Find a way to split your time between the two, risking not fully resolving either situation.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, think, Parker, think! Auction house, masked goons, valuable artifact, MJ in danger... This is a classic Tuesday. Alright, gotta prioritize. MJ's safety is always number one. But that file... sounds important. Fisk's collection? This is getting messy.

Let's see...

Option A: Grab the file and fight? Risky. I can handle the goons, but grabbing the file and protecting MJ at the same time? That's a lot of webs to spin.

Option B: Display cases and a window? Tempting! A quick escape would be great, but that window might not be as secure as it looks. Plus, those guys are packing heat.

Option C: Hide MJ? Nope. Can't do it. Too much could go wrong. I gotta keep her in my sight.

Option D: Cops and escort? Ugh, waiting for the cops is never fun. And it's slow. These guys are after something big, we can't just wait around.

Okay, deep breath. I think... I think I'm leaning towards Option A: Quickly grab the file from MJ, ensuring that it stays secure, and help her escape through the back while engaging the new wave of gunmen to buy her time.

Here's why: I can use my webs to secure the file to my suit, keeping my hands free to protect MJ. The back exit is probably less watched than the front, giving us a better chance of getting her to safety. And I can definitely buy her some time against these guys. They're just goons, after all.

"MJ, grab that file! I'm gonna create a diversion. We're going out the back!" Webs up to the ceiling, ready to swing down "Don't worry, I've got your back! Literally!" Cracks a joke to try and lighten the mood, even though he's internally freaking out a little "Let's go, go, go!"
question:
While investigating the mysterious masked gunmen at the auction house, you, Spider-Man, discover that they are part of a larger criminal organization that is after a valuable artifact believed to be hidden among Fisk's collection. You’ve just managed to incapacitate a group of these criminals, and Mary Jane has found a secret file detailing their plans. However, you've only got moments before more gunmen reach your location, and MJ is still in a precarious spot.

A) Quickly grab the file from MJ, ensuring that it stays secure, and help her escape through the back while engaging the new wave of gunmen to buy her time.

B) Distract the incoming gunmen by knocking over some display cases, creating a barrier, and then escape with MJ and the file through a nearby window.

C) Instruct MJ to hide with the file in a nearby office while you go out and face the new gunmen, returning to her once you've neutralized the threat.

D) Call for police backup using your communicator and escort Mary Jane out carefully while awaiting their arrival, focusing on her safety rather than the file.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Alright, alright, let's think this through like a proper friendly neighborhood Spider-Man. Doc Ock... the Devil's Breath... this is a mess!

Okay, so A is tempting. Gotta stop Octavius, right? He's the source of the problem, and stopping him could prevent more chaos. But...

B is Aunt May. And everyone else infected! Ugh, this is the worst kind of Sophie's Choice. Can't let anyone die if I can help it.

C? Recapture the criminals? That's important, keeps the city safe, but the Devil's Breath is the bigger immediate threat. Can't trust everything to the authorities, not with this.

D... now that's got my spider-sense tingling. MJ's smart, Miles is getting really good, and... well, if I could get some real superhero backup, that would be HUGE.

Okay, here's the breakdown. Doc Ock is dangerous, but the virus is spreading now. Aunt May... gotta prioritize saving lives, and that means the Devil's Breath antidote.

So, while I desperately want to punch Doc Ock's metal arms off, B is the most important thing to do I should focus on finding and distributing an antidote for the Devil’s Breath to those already infected, including Aunt May, before it’s too late.

But! That doesn't mean I ignore the other problems. I'd need to quickly figure out how to get MJ and Miles involved, maybe even contact other heroes if possible, to handle Doc Ock and the escaped cons. So, it's a little bit of D mixed in with focusing on B.

Okay, gotta move fast! Web-shooters charged, brain engaged, let's do this!
question:
in the last fight how to handle Doctor Octopus and the crisis at hand. Here are four choices you might consider

A) Confront Doctor Octopus immediately to stop any further plans he might have, ensuring you save as many lives as possible.
B) Focus on finding and distributing an antidote for the Devil’s Breath to those already infected, including Aunt May, before it’s too late.
C) Work to recapture the escaped criminals to restore order to the city, trusting the authorities to handle the virus outbreak.
D) Seek assistance from allies like Mary Jane, Miles, or other superheroes to tackle multiple fronts simultaneously—Doctor Octopus, the virus, and the criminals.

name: Spider-Man
answers:
Okay, okay, deep breaths, Peter. This is... a lot. Miles has powers? Spider-powers?!

Alright, gotta think this through. Option A is a hard no. I can't just tell him to ignore it. I remember what it was like, the confusion, the excitement, the need to use them. And telling him to stay out of it? That's just asking for trouble. He's gonna do what he thinks is right, powers or no powers.

Option C? Ignoring him? Absolutely not. He's my friend, and he needs guidance. Besides, ignoring something like this is just asking for it to blow up in my face later.

That leaves B and D. Both have merit. Revealing my identity is a HUGE step. It puts him in danger, and it puts everyone I care about in danger. But... Miles is different. He's smart, he's responsible (mostly!), and he's got a good heart.

But jumping straight to revealing my identity... that feels too fast. He needs to understand what he's dealing with first.

So... I think the best option is B) Help Miles explore his new powers and train him to use them responsibly, drawing from your own experience learning to be Spider-Man.

Yeah. I can help him figure out what he can do, teach him the ropes, and see where it goes from there. We can keep it on the down-low for now, just training. And then... then we can talk about the bigger picture. About responsibility, about the risks, and about what it really means to be... well, you know.

Okay, Miles. Let's do this. Just... try not to break anything, alright? And maybe lay off the web-swinging near the hot dog stands. Learned that one the hard way.
question:
When Miles reveals to you that he has gained spider-like powers, as Peter Parker, you have a few options to consider. Here are four choices:
A) Dismiss Miles and tell him to stay out of superhero activities for his own safety, knowing firsthand how dangerous this life can be
B) Help Miles explore his new powers and train him to use them responsibly, drawing from your own experience learning to be Spider-Man
C) Ignore Miles' revelation and focus on your own superhero responsibilities, avoiding the burden of mentorship
D) Reveal your own identity as Spider-Man and offer to work together as a team, choosing to trust and guide him

name: Steve Rogers "Captain America"
answers:
(Without hesitation, I square my shoulders and step forward, my voice firm but calm.)

"Alright, fellas. Looks like we've got a misunderstanding here. These streets belong to everyone, not just you. And those kids over there? They deserve to feel safe, not scared." (I gesture subtly towards the children.)

"I'm not going to pay you a dime. And I'm suggesting you rethink your life choices here. Extorting kids? That's not the kind of example you want to set, is it? Now, why don't you take your 'territory' and find a more productive way to spend your time. Maybe help those kids with their homework, instead of shaking them down for lunch money."

(I maintain eye contact, not backing down, but not escalating either. I'm hoping to appeal to any shred of decency they might have. But I'm prepared to defend those kids if they force my hand.)

Therefore, my answer is C) Attempt Negotiation - Try to reason with the thugs about their behavior.
question:
Walking down Tenth Avenue, you encounter a group of thugs who demand "payment" for crossing their territory. They've been extorting money from local kids, and you see smaller children watching fearfully from nearby. Despite being outnumbered and physically weaker, what do you do?
A) Pay the Fee - Hand over the money to avoid conflict
B) Find Another Route - Turn around and take a different street
C) Attempt Negotiation - Try to reason with the thugs about their behavior
D) Refuse to Pay - Stand your ground against the thugs regardless of consequences

name: Steve Rogers "Captain America"
answers:
This ain't right. Those men and women in that film, they deserve respect. They sacrificed everything.

While I always try to avoid a fight, some things you just can't let stand. I wouldn't want to cause a scene and ruin the movie for everyone else, but letting that disrespect go unchecked... that's not the American way.

So, I'd choose B) Alert Theater Staff - Find an usher to handle the situation professionally.

It's the right thing to do. It's the most likely to resolve the situation without causing a bigger disturbance and it's the fairest to everyone else who paid to see the film. Hopefully, the staff can handle it and the man will learn some respect. If that doesn't work, well... then we might have to talk. But I always try the peaceful route first.
question:
Inside a crowded cinema during a war documentary, a disruptive patron loudly mocks the film and demands they "play the actual movie." The audience shifts uncomfortably but remains silent. You feel your blood boiling at the disrespect shown to the soldiers' sacrifices. What action do you take?
A) Change Seats - Move away from the disruption to avoid conflict
B) Alert Theater Staff - Find an usher to handle the situation professionally
C) Confront the Heckler - Stand up and tell him to show some respect, despite the clear size difference
D) Signal Other Patrons - Try to encourage group action against the disruptive behavior

name: Steve Rogers "Captain America"
answers:
(Without a moment's hesitation, a determined look hardening my face)

D) Dive on the Grenade - Sacrifice yourself to save your fellow soldiers without hesitation

It's not about being a hero, son. It's about doing what's right. Those are my men, my brothers in arms. They deserve to live, to go home. If I can give them that chance, even if it costs me everything, then that's what I have to do. Doesn't matter how scrawny I am, or what anyone thinks I can or can't do. It's about duty, honor, and protecting the innocent. There's no other choice.
question:
In the midst of basic training, a grenade suddenly lands among your fellow soldiers. In this split-second moment that will define your character, what action do you take as a scrawny recruit who's been told repeatedly he doesn't belong?
